Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. See Yew

kVCP515lRJw3gKrxFEnlgw.text: The honey took me here per their colleague's recommendation....and I continue to be disappointed in Pittsburgh's food offerings.   Don't get me wrong. It's not terrible. Just not good either.  I'll start with the ambiance. It was very cute, albeit a bit dark. I liked the happy plants that greeted you at the door, and the bouquet up in the front was formidable. Huge. Big plant energy everywhere.  We were seated quickly, and our server was very nice. Not a lot of small talk (my kind of server), but checked on us an appropriate amount. Enough to at least make sure we didn't cause any trouble, haha.  I ordered the Chiang Mai curry, and bae, the street noodles #1. The menu made it abundantly clear that the restaurant considered spice as no joke. I believed them, so I ordered the spice level in number 4. "Thai spicy" in their words. This was my first mistake.  There was maybe enough spice to make a member of the Weenie Hut Jr feel cool they could tolerate it, but to make actual heat seekers ask themselves, "what?" It just wasn't spicy. And normally I could overlook that, but the sauce/curry had little flavor of its own. It tasted like what I'd imagine coconut milk would taste like if it got waitlisted to become Penang curry. Just weak.   My partner, however, didn't mind their entree. They particularly liked the chicken on their street noodles. I sampled his dish, and it was better than mine, but again, not great.   In terms of price, I felt that it was fair. Our noodle dishes were $9.50 each. It's cash only, which was strange but not an issue for us, haha.   But yes, I'm giving it three stars, because it reminded me of my college years eating Tin Drum. Only minus the unlimited Thai tea. And because service and ambiance were lovely. I see myself begrudgingly eating here once the move is finalized.   Please Pittsburgh, make better Asian food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chang Mai Noodles + Street Noodle #1

qo4vbAsUKO0lCDK0-Z8dUw.text: Important: Cash only I had the street noodles #1 with medium heat, and it was absolutely fantastic. The chicken breading was light and crispy, though I did have a few slices that were over cooked but the flavor and the rest of the dish was enough to save it. The broth had well developed flavors with just the right amount of heat and acidity. I thought I was having their best dish up until I tasted the shrimp pad Thai. The pad Thai was potentially the best I've ever had with a balance of sweet and salty balanced with the perfect amount of tamarind and acidity that elevates the naturally savory flavors.

zEy04_OG1jC-zupQH11j2g.text: Favorite place for Thai food in Pittsburgh! The wait can be long at peak dinner hours but it's well worth the wait. The tofu kee mao is one of my favorites. Be careful with the spice level though, I can usually handle spicy food but even the level 2 spice was spicy enough for me

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Kee Mao with tofu (front) and Pad Thai (back)

MOBX5PsvGIairA_INHxdXA.text: I've been to Noodlehead so many times and despite the crowds, it's always worth it and worth the wait. Obviously, it's BYOB and cash only and you can now order online for take out.   You can't go wrong with any of the appetizers. Spring rolls come in two and are crunchy and delicious with a dipping sauce. The sweet potato triangles come in six and are also delicious, sweet, crunchy, and served with their own sauce. Dumplings are served in fours with a soy sauce type dipping sauce and the steamed pork buns are served in a pair. The pour is succulent and juicy and the bun is like a delicious little pillow.   The Sukothai is full of flavor and has everything you could want and is a great portion for $6.50. I love the street noodle one - the chicken is perfectly battered and crispy and served in a delicious sauce with noodles and veggies. Street noodles 2 is basically the shrimp version.   Kee Mao is a great traditional noodle dish and served with the wide noodles. I prefer the chicken but the shrimp is always delicious (I've never had the tofu). The Pad Thai is consistently perfect and always a great option when you don't know what to get.   My advice would be rounding down when picking a spice level. From my experience, it seems like sometimes the spice level varies so better to be safe than sorry.

wAScUhFJDFV-YYwmJ6xIwA.text: FINALLY had my first Noodlehead experience. It was on my "must try" list for some time, believe me when I say it's as good (maybe even better) then everyone makes it out to be.  First - yes, you have to wait. They do not have a phone, you can't make reservations or use no wait. Do the old school-thing where you actually go and talk to someone and wait for your table to be ready. On the positive side, if you're a Noodlehead take out regular you can now order online!  Second - cash only. Even if you order online you must pay in store with cash upon pick up. If you forget, they have an ATM on site.   Third - the menu isn't huge, but you'll find staples dishes here. I had the See Yew with chicken. Highly recommend if you love the wide noodles. Wide the spice rating! I love the heat, but even a 2 was enough for me. Like the menu says - you can always add more, but you can't take it out.   Fourth - It's also BYOB so don't forget to bring a bottle of wine!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

PbFL6prwFeyHx7yR45iW0g.text: I mean, I definitely get it. I got takeout here tonight with a friend who literally raves about this place 24/7. We got the see yew (spelling may be way off) with chicken and the sweet potato triangles. Both were great and honestly so affordable! I'm glad we got takeout because when we got there the line outside was crazy.  Here's the reason for not 5: I've had Thai from less known places that is just as good if not just slightly better (in my opinion of course). Also, we tried to go there once and eat in, and the hostess very, VERY shortly told us she would not seat a table of 4 for the rest of the evening due to the crowd. I totally get it, but she was extremely curt and sarcastic. Didn't love that. However, you can't deny the food is good. If you want to experience the hype, I. D.o.n.t think you'll be disappointed.

T_-PSBuuyMZyRLJxE_SQAg.text: This was our first time ordering from Noodlehead! We loved it after traveling to Thailand this spring, and having a little taste of our vacation was great! We loved being able to pick up the food and walk out with it because we live nearby it's the easiest for us! Make sure you bring cash

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Take home pad Thai w tofu
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Take home Chaing mai

w3ltRhKKWsm1MdK_jpGzSA.text: Noodlehead was absolutely delicious. The flavor in the Street Noodle #1 was spectacular. I don't typically eat Thai so I wasn't sure what to expect. I loved it! I got spicy level 2 and it was the perfect amount of spice.   The atmosphere of the restaurant is super cute but not practical. The stools we sat on didn't allow for any place for my purse or jacket to hang. It might be helpful to have a coat hanger or purse hook on the table.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street Noodle #1

faU9TN49xAzya1YrEJPEFg.text: The decor is wonderful here. I love the wood and all the plants that surround the dining room. The service is great and I appreciate their low BYOB fee. Although there isn't any alcoholic drinks, I was impressed with all their other beverage offerings. I got the Red Ribbon mint ginger-ale and it did not disappoint.   I ordered the Chiang Mai curry. I'm not much of a spicy fan so I ordered it with level 1 spice. The dish was very tasty and full of different flavors and textures. The broth was very creamy with some sweetness that blended great with the spice. The chicken added some additional flavor to the dish and was cooked properly. My favorite part of the Chiang Main curry was definitely the crispy noodles that topped the dish; I enjoyed crunching them down into the broth and eating them that way, with the right amount of crunch.   I'm giving this place a 4/5 stars because I wasn't really wowed by my dining experience. I would like to try this place again and get more food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Curry

s3PnaIKSCKH-qW0rJ4J-mQ.text: I heard of this place from locals but wasn't sure what the hype was about before I tried it; now i know! I went on a late lunch on a weekday so didn't had to wait. I liked their menu because it features some Thai street food/dishes that i haven't heard of. I tried the Sukotahi noodle soup and was blown away how sour soup can be so refreshing. I loved the lemongrass smell to it and the meatballs that came with the soup was so delicious. I was also surprised how affordable the prices of the menu were.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sukothai

SF8wt5Hkt-PMNQw_Xh_O-g.text: I have to say -- I am pleasantly surprised by the service of this place. Previously, I had written a review about how I was mortified and disappointed by a takeout experience. As soon as the review was posted, I received a message from a higher-up with an apology and offer for either a complete refund or 2 complimentary dishes. As I said before, I still really enjoy Noodlehead. So I skeptically went back with a friend.  As promised, I did not get charged for our dishes. They did not skimp out on the portion either, even though they knew that it would be for free. I really appreciate Noodlehead's customer service and Pam, who messaged me, for offering such a genuine apology and generous compensation.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Takeout see yew with chicken with a hair in it

QogdlZMDQZ9NLUbJrEREYA.text: Quite "Americanized" Thai food, i.e sweet and spicy for dishes not all spicy in Thailand Service is bad, long waiting time despite several seatings left unattended for 15mn or more, asked to order once we got the table but staff didn't care, waiters doing so many trips empty handed ; basically poorly managed.

u9QnMU7fkgUzqZpYLaTLdg.text: You have to try this place!  I heard rumors that this place was a must go to place in pittsburgh and wow were the rumors True! I was told that their Pad Thai was something they were well known for. However I decided to try the other options on their menu such as the Love Boat and Kee Moa to see if they had more to offer than just their Pad Thai. I gotta say I'm surprised no one is talking about either of those dishes because they're simply amazing! I wasn't disappointed at all in my order and thankful I branched out in trying dishes I'm not as familiar with!   Something I appreciated was the fast order time and quick service, the place was PACKED but I was in and out with no problems. Other things I enjoyed about noodlehead was their simplified menu choices! None of that shuffling through 3 pages of options, rather one double sided page that gives the entire selection.   Overall I would love to come back here again and try their Pad Thai next time, I'm sure not to be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Kee Moa
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Inside Noodlehead
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Love Boat

4q2Jz0bzFx39c-j8-2d4Mw.text: I've lost count of how many times I've been here and how many times I recommend this place to my friends.  * Food: I've gotten almost all their noodle dishes and my go-to is always the See Yew. I love thicker noodles in general and I appreciate the addition of the eggs in the dish. I would say that there was one or two times where I felt the sauce was a tiny bit salty but overall, I can't get enough of this dish. For people who are new to this place, I usually recommend the pad thai. You can never go wrong with that!             You get to pick the spice level from a 0-5. I will say that the spiciness always differ even when you pick the same number each time but it isn't something that deters me from giving this place less stars.              I haven't tried the appetizers but that will definitely be my goal next time!  * Cost vs. Worth: Most of their noodle dishes are $9.5 (this place only accepts cash by the way!). If they charged more like $12, I'd still come back to this place.   Will I come here again? - I think you already know the answer to this.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. See Yew with chicken

VzkGEfeOZZ5vVKERrACldw.text: Good ambiance, great food, and in a wonderful part of the city. It's also BYOB! Beware, their spiciness levels are no joke! There's also a cute outdoor eating area, perfect for summer date nights.

ebmYwWozFHovkXnqu2qj0w.text: Super delicious! I ordered 'street noodle 1,' which was rice noodles with Thai fried chicken. It also had bok choy, bean sprouts and cilantro. You can customize your spice level, but I stuck with zero.   It was also pretty crowded, but because we were a party of 2, we were offered seating at the window, which had a long stretch of table where you could look out onto the street, so luckily we didn't have to wait.   They accept cash only, so come prepared! But in case you're running low, they have an ATM on site.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodle 1
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

4xSyIF-fb7C7vRZSsSXYIw.text: Hit up the ATM before visiting this cash only spot for some out-of-this-world noodles.   We actually started with the Pork Belly Steamed Buns from the Snacks menu. This was a wonderful couple of bites to momentarily subdue our growling bellies.  My local friend's favorite noodle dish is the Street Noodle #1, a combination of rice noodles, Thai fried chicken, bok choy, bean sprouts, and cilantro. There is a large scale of spiciness here at Noodlehead, but let us assure you that even the #2 (medium) on the spicy scale is very comfortably spicy! I love spice, but can't see myself getting anything spicier than that while still enjoying my meal. I tried a couple bites of her noodles, and really enjoyed the flavor! This is a solid choice.  I decided to get the Chiang Mai Curry, which features egg noodles, chicken, pickled mustard greens, bean sprouts, and crispy shallots in a yellow curry coconut milk sauce. It's so saucy that it honestly makes me think it's borderline soup. I would have loved an Asian soup spoon to get more of the broth with each bite, but settled for a regular spoon and my chopsticks to pluck at the noodles.  I really enjoyed this spot and would highly recommend it to my fellow noodleheads. Great noodle selection, and then some!

jhvY2y9gf_XgcFx1o8Lbkg.text: Yes!!!  Yummy savory slurpy noodles First off it's a cash only  But totally going and find that paper so you can eat here or take out. Starvin Marvin one cold fall day  I wanted something hot filling and comforting And take out because of time Menu is pretty simple  They have noodlely soups  And noodle dishes Pick your noodle your sauce veggie tofu meat or chicken Savory noodles with veggies was delish and ready in 5 min Nicely packed piping hot It was so goood  Service very friendly looks like a good place to sit, relax and enjoy maybe next People with big bowls looking very happy  Prices are easy 6.50 for soups 9.50 for noodle dishes  It's all good plus you can eat them with the quality chopsticks they give. I will be back  The biggest issue is the parking almost anytime of the day it's a hassle such is this street

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delish savory

wsPjTMjP3jlpmBdPIn8ycw.text: Amazing spot! My favorites are the kee mao and chiang mai curry!

PXHUi_LwI0Jc_T9UQvyeAA.text: Absolutely amazing! Went on a Thursday night and the service was really fast; food came soon after we ordered it. Food was amazing as well. Huge portions, easily two meals worth. Great value & amazing food. Highly recommend for anytime you're in the PGH Shadyside area. They don't take credit cards, but do have an ATM if you forgot to bring cash.

3Wegn6OO5sNVAMoBtBNGXw.text: High-quality food at reasonable prices. I came here on a recommendation from a friend and I was pleasantly surprised. We were seated almost immediately even though the restaurant seemed crowded. Great atmosphere but the lighting is a little dark. Food was superb. They give you multiple levels of spiciness to choose from depending on your preference. I would definitely recommend.

EV5qNWWTej5Y2A9Qj0SwDQ.text: I come here all the time- the food is amazing and flavorful (even if you don't like spice, you can opt for zero spice or just a little). Large portions for a great price especially if you're of the college age. Word to the wise though - it's cash only, dinner time you will always wait, and you need to have the whole party with you when you are seated. I promise it's worth it though

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. BYOB for a small corkage fee (50 cents a person)
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green Curry Linguine

Adl0jifMuG0S0Vzow0Uedg.text: Cash only, super affordable, BYOB with a low corking fee, and SO YUMMY. Casual but still feels fancy. I eat here at least once a month.

gn6MctSnuTi57m5fSfJjjQ.text: The food was good but the staff was rude. There were a number of people waiting to eat and they kept telling us to move because we were in the way but as soon as we moved they told us again (this happened 3 times). They were also rude to a woman in a wheelchair who was waiting despite her attempt to also make enough room for people to walk by. The stools to wait have a seat that screws off and one fell apart for another customer as they were getting up so thankfully they did not fall over. Also only one of the two female toilets was functioning.

rM3hglC5M-pi3OwkQUAq_Q.text: This place was fantastic! Upon arriving there were at least 30 people waiting outside, and we waited for about 45 minutes- it was definitely worth it! Spring rolls and potato wedges were ok, but the Love Boat soup was AMAZING!!! Warning though, I love extra hot food, and the 3 was pushing it for me- don't underestimate how spicy the soup is! The pad Thai, pictured, I also ordered at a 3, and didn't seem as hot as the soup. Hands down I would recommend the Love Boat soup! Bring your own milk or stop by the ice cream shop next door afterward ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

oxHWfoGQYCbFBo8o2_Zacg.text: In a nutshell: Hip, modern and affordable. Small menu of some appetizers and Thai noodles. Cash only.   I really enjoyed Noodlehead. You can tell the quality of food when the place is packed and there are packs of people standing at the door waiting for a table. My husband and I came here on a Friday night and it looked incredibly busy, but the wait was only 15 minutes. We ordered the Sweet Potato Triangles for our appetizer, he ordered the Kee Mao and I ordered the Street Noodle #1. The sweet potato triangles were mashed sweet potato, wrapped in spring roll wrapper and deep fried, served alongside a light cucumber sauce. These were AMAZING. They were sweet, crunchy and when paired with the sauce, OMG. The refreshing cucumber cuts through the heaviness of the deep fried shell. The Kee Mao was delicious, but really spicy. My husband ordered spice level 1 and it was too spicy for the both of us. I also want to note that we are not sensitive to spice, as I typically order a 6 at other Thai places when I'm in the mood for mild spice. I ordered a 2 spice level for my street noodle #1 and it was perfect. The sauce was a sweet and spicy sauce. It's similar to Pad Thai, yet completely different. The noodles were very saucy, but it was perfect to dip the chicken in.   I would give Noodlehead 4.5 stars. I loved everything about this place except for the over spice on my husband's Kee Mao, despite its low spice level. Maybe it was a mix up in the kitchen so I'm definitely willing to go back to give it another try.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Kee Mao
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodle #1 (and Kee Mao in the background)
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sweet potato triangles

j4lNSoGodg7blbom0ECQiw.text: The street noodles #1 and curry were excellent.  When asian restaurants like this one don't fill their menu with 100 similarly tasting dishes and instead focus on a few really good menu items, this is what it tastes like.

tMOmnfozgAQUyQlpNGTR9Q.text: This place absolutely rocks. I'm not surprised Noodlehead is so loved and consistently packed even though the 2 previous restaurants in this space weren't able to survive. The dishes are so tasty and reasonably priced. It's really fun and family friendly. BYOB is an added bonus.   The Chiangmai curry is my go-to dish but we're also big fans of the Pad Thai. And don't forget about the pork buns!

GRj2s65NPal0UybHJymwdg.text: The food was so good. If you are looking for something spicy and tasty. Here is your best choice.

880fJ47Z002jEmaefDzNqA.text: Love love love everything on their menu--you could pick anything without being disappointed. Also I love the authentic spiciness. If you ask for hot you will get HOT. The only reason I can't give them five stars is bc every time I go they are super busy which makes it hard for staff to be attentive. A few times my order has been mixed up. But they are always quick to fix it! Overall great prices, great food, and a very hip atmosphere.

oEl-As4U5u0Gm5jcqf_sAQ.text: Considering Thai is my favorite food group (lol) I am on a mission to try all of the Thai that the Burgh has to offer. My mom is a Thai lover as well- so on a beautiful Fall Friday when I had the afternoon off work, we visited Noodlehead. There is some outside seating, but it was a little chilly so we sat indoors.   Here are a couple things you need to know before visiting: 1. CASH ONLY 2. BYOB! (Only a 50 cents "recycling" fee per person) 3. Parking isn't the best- we paid to park at a meter outside of Noodlehead. There is residential parking but it's permit.   Our server was nice & attentive to our table despite being very busy with a late lunch rush. She brought us glasses for our wine & a pitcher of water for the table shortly after our arrival. We ordered the pork belly steamed buns to start. I heard awesome things & had to try them. For our entrees, we ordered the chicken pad thai (spiciness at a 3), street noodles #1 (spiciness at a 3) with chicken & the beef soup (spiciness at a 1).  Pork belly steamed buns- I have always wanted to try these little adorable Thai sandwiches but wasn't sure where to find them before Noodlehead. They were good & very simple. Basically just BBQ pork in a steamed bun with some pickled cucumber on top. I added sriracha to mine to add some spicy flavor- they literally weren't spicy at all without it. At two per order for $6, there aren't a bad deal- just not as flavorful as I had hoped.  Street Noodles #1- The chicken was AWESOME in this. For $9, the portion of noodles I received was large & the amount of chicken I received was awesome as well. The chicken was fried but the batter was more fluffy than fried tasting. Really tasty. The noodles were disappointing. I understand that Fish Sauce is in A LOT of Thai. I'm not a fish person AT ALL, but I deal with it. In 99% of the Thai restaurants that I have been to, I can't taste the fish sauce in their food. Usually I can't even smell it. This dish was the exception. It had completely too much fish sauce in it. I tried to neutralize it by adding Sriracha- didn't work. I didn't eat much of this dish in the restaurant because I hoped I could "doctor it up" at home by adding sesame oil, soy sauce & chili oil, to make it less fishy. I couldn't even eat them then. I'm not sure if it was just a bad day or if these noodles are always this fishy but I wasn't impressed at all with this dish.  Beef Soup- My mom really liked this. I am not really a beef soup person, but the bite I tried was tasty. It had a slight spicy kick to it, which was nice. The portion was huge- what she didn't eat at the restaurant, she had for dinner the next day.  Chicken pad thai- Still fishy. Not as fishy as Street Noodles by ANY means, but it was still fishy. We added fresh lime juice & Sriracha & that seemed to do the trick of neutralizing the fish sauce. After adding those ingredients we really enjoyed it.  I don't want to give Noodlehead two stars- I love the decor of this place, it's rustic & modern, yet still Thai feeling, the presentation of the noodles were great & I am a fan of the prices & the fact that they are BYOB. But I can't give them a good rating considering two dishes we ordered were overpowered with fish sauce. If I have to take a dish home in order to make it better, then the restaurant didn't deliver like they should have. The pork belly steamed buns were also disappointing. I ended up ordering some to-go for the boyfriend & he thought they were bland as well.  I would be willing to return.. everyone seems to love this place, so maybe I just came on a bad day.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Byob!
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork belly steamed buns
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodles and pad Thai

amltvEsLCOelhjI5wSXZHg.text: As someone who loves exploring new noodle options, Noodlehead was shockingly disappointing. There are plenty of better options in Pittsburgh to choose from, so don't settle unless it's extremely convenient.   Ambiance: South Highland and the surrounding East End / Shadyside area is always a great place to be, especially without side seating in the summer. The inside is a quirky rustic, which they pull off very well. In general, my biggest qualm (other than the okay food) is that they are cash only. While I do understand, it's incredibly inconvenient. In addition, they don't have a phone so you can't call ahead for Togo orders. I would agree that noodles are best fresh and you should likely enjoy them as soon as possible, it's inconvenient when you live near by and end up waiting 20 minutes in the cold for your order.   Food: After hearing all the rave, I took my mom to Noodlehead when she came to visit. We enjoyed the outside seating and ordered the Street food #1 and the Pad see Yew at the waitress's recommendation. My mom ended up eating the chicken off the #1 which was good but not supposed to be the main event.   I'm sure I will inevitably be drug back and hope my opinion changes. Noodlehead has the perfect location and the right food style to be my most frequented near by restaurant (I will just need more cash).

AvLCNi69P19CargkJTQqMA.text: Very reasonably priced and delicious food in a cozy atmosphere. Service was prompt and courteous. I had the vegetarian Kee Maw at level 4 spiciness and it was flavorful with just the right amount of heat. Will definitely go there again soon!

V-TTLvZPUwrTVRhR8hLFDw.text: Visited around 6 PM on a Sunday and proceeded to stand in the foyer area confused for several minutes because there were plenty of seats but no one seeming to be taking anyone to them. Apparently a lot of people were waiting for/ordering takeout which created the bottleneck. Facilitating a way to better distinguish dine-in vs. takeout would help...  Eventually, we were seated. The ambiance was nice enough... certainly had a hipster-ish vibe though which straddles the line between cool and pretentious. We ordered spring rolls, street noodles 2 and kee mao. The service was satisfactory. The food was also good and relatively inexpensive but I can't say it was any better than other Thai dishes I had elsewhere. The portions however- specifically my street noodles - were also small. I'd happily pay a few extra dollars to leave not still hungry.  Sometimes I feel like certain places collapse under the weight of their inflated yelp reviews and to me this was the case here.

KySpzy6mxGzXToDK13ih7Q.text: This is a cool spot the my favorite thing was the sweet potato triangles they are full of flavor and moist. Pork Buns were also very good. My least favorite thing was the pork dumplings they were very dry and bland.

Jfl4W0Wo9rP8zncrqxpatw.text: Noodlehead is my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. I can't eat Pork Buns or Kee Mao anywhere else.   The service is quick - I've never had to wait more than 15 min even when it's busy. It is cash only, which can be a bit of a pain, but there is an ATM in the back. The rustic decor is amazing and the outdoor seating can be busy, but is pet friendly!

9ATAI7p7sj6PQJ5esJuYVw.text: Ordered: Pad Thai - Thai Spicy (Chicken), Steamed Baos, and the Thai Fried Chicken  as good as advertised for sure, pad Thai had a nice spice to it, kind of sneaks up on you and lingers a bit.  The baos were nice and soft, a bit oily but full of flavor.  Chicken had a nice crunch to it, cooked quickly because the chicken was beat flat, kind of like a mix of chicken fried steak with popcorn chicken.

DTY6NgpyLlKpaX1pa-yoZQ.text: I was eating out so much lately that I just can't have any more of the oily, fatty, crappy food prepared with a "I hate my job and life attitude" they give you in lots of the places. Noodlehead does not have a lot of variety but what they have is freaking delicious. We had the pork buns and even though I am usually not a big fan of pork buns, I couldn't get enough of the ones here. The texture and the flavor combinations is absolutely divine. As a main I had the Chiang Mai Curry and boy was it good. Again, perfect texture, enough chicken, taste was incredible and I couldn't stop eating. You choose between a spice level of 1 -5 . I had 1 and that was more than enough for me (I cannot handle spice well though). If you can't finish the portion, ask for a takeaway box.  Staff was patient with us, quick and super friendly. Nice outdoor seating is available as well. They definitely have found a new regular customer!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiangmai curry! Yum!

3v6JRRzd3aib_iKSegRZ0A.text: I loooove me some Noodlehead. It's come to be a regular option for so many kinds of meals: a birthday dinner with coworkers, an impromptu gabfest with a girlfriend (in which we may or may not have scurried over in gym leggings and/or scrubs), a first (or fourth) date, or a catch-up with my brother (for whom Noodlehead was the ticket to him falling in love with Thai food!). The pad thai (my preference = with those perfect tiny shrimp!) is now an old standby, but Street Noodle #1 is an equally viable option. I've also been lusting after the Chiang Mai curry as of late. Don't forget a steamed pork bun or two to tide you over.

2T1TS_gyt_CYulHP5tcwMw.text: We love this place. The servers are so kind. We've been going since our daughter was 2 months old and one server knows us well. The pork buns are to die for.  Get the outdoor table if you can - and bring some cold beer to cut the spicyness.

jAzg0opGDLLspEGq4LcWLQ.text: It is the first place I would think of when I'm craving for noodles. Most dishes taste pretty close to authentic Thai noodles. At least the food here helps me not miss Thailand so much. :) My favorites are love boat and beef soup.

gAa2HSB2_VClVQFqfLPEsw.text: One of my all time favorite Shadyside spots! When my husband and I lived in Shadyside this was one of our go to date nights!  Seating is tough and there is no phone, but it is worth the wait!  I have never had a bad meal here.  The pork buns are to die for and just melt in your mouth!  The noodle portions are huge!! Remember to bring a bottle of wine with you as it is BYOB.

AeWEQnL1tqywlglZPtO2wA.text: The pork buns are absolutely amazing. The rest of their food is good, but definitely takes a back seat to the pork buns.  cash-only, don't forget to hit the ATM on your way over.

vjRT8jpYoZle1lZicId5SQ.text: Location's a pain to get to from campus but...the chicken.   Street Noodle #1 is fried chicken cutlet perfection on top of flavorful, (spicy) noodles. Even if you get "a little" bit of spicy, which I stupidly let the waiter talk me into getting, it will be HOT.  This is apparently not the case for Street Noodle #2, which is fried shrimp, on top of egg noodles which are considerably drier, and less spicy.    Even with the unbearable burn in my mouth, I was able to enjoy the fried chicken.  The noodles, I couldn't finish :(   Restaurant is dim and spacey, with a 50cent BYOB per head charge.

9tMhUy_uUs_T5GRAVtLMKw.text: Well yelp nation I am back after a long hiatus. I guess my pontificating kinda wore thin even on me so I too a little break for about two years. I mark my return with a trip and review to Noodle Head in Shadyside. I've been to NH a number of times and I feel it is about time I pile in the praise they deserve.   To start, as I usually do, let's discuss the decor. The interior can only be described as cool. Not pretentious cool but a pleasant mix of plastic seating, to reflect their roots in Thai street food, and dark wood. I felt very comfortable, as did the hipsters sitting next to me, and the businessmen next to them.   I also live NHs bar options. It's BYO so if the wine sucks, it'd your fault. To go with the BYO liquor license they do have a corkage fee, but it's only fifty cents a person  which I think is very reasonable.   The food at NH is amazing. I am a fan if the sliced beef appetizer as well as the steamed pork belly buns. For an entree my standby us the Ching Mai curry. The flavor of the curry is out if this world. Pickled veg with coconut milk and a crazy amount of spice. Fantastic. Don't fear spice here. They utilize a 1-5 heat scale (I'm a 4) but even in the hottest dishes the spice doesn't overwhelm the flavor of the rest of the food.    The only thing they lose a star for is service. The staff always seems to be inconvenienced by the guests. They aren't mean or rude but they give off the impression that they would rather be doing something else.   All in all I love NH. So many times Thai food just gets caught in an inferno if chili heat that the food loses all it's flavor and you pay out the rectum (literally) the next day.  Not so here and despite being cash only I plan in going back. Often.

IwAUSZ-HusDSIXTFGq8IhA.text: Our favorite Thai place in Pittsburgh -- everything we've tried here has been awesome: the pork belly sliders, pad thai, chiang mai noodles,  sukothai, street noodles #1, and beef noodle soup. Their menu is small which is a good thing. It seems they are focused on consistently delivering a few dishes, instead of overwhelming the customer with too many options and mediocre food.

RFoKiBI7O-5EFy5apCg_Iw.text: Noodlehead is amazing! the restaurant has a great atmosphere to sit down and eat with friends, but always good for take out too (usually a 5-10 min wait). Pad Thai is beyond delicious, it's BYOB and they even have some outdoor seating. Service is also great. 100% recommend!

_ButekRWHiostm9yfU4_Hw.text: I had the chicken pad thai, level zero heat, and the lemongrass iced tea. The pad thai could've used a little more lime, but overall had a lot of flavor. I couldn't taste the lemongrass in the tea, but it was also decent.  Ambiance gets an A. It's a bit dimly lit and noisy, but there are people who look for that in an evening outing. The menu's a bit limited, but if you're looking for good noodles, you'll be satisfied.

s_3yvSgN7UoHqsvB1wKzpg.text: My first impressions weren't great but the food was good. The restaurant has a steel-and-wood look more suited to a bar, and floors were sticky - a huge turn-off for me. We were seated quickly at a large rectangular wood table with long benches for seats. Our waitress was hurried but nice. I had a taste for iced tea but they don't serve standard black tea so I skipped the drink and had only water. The kee mao was delicious but I didn't care for the overly sweet see ew. My kids have more of a sweet tooth and enjoyed it. Be warned about the spice level you ask for though. I've eaten spicy foods in Indonesia and Thailand that will burn your tastebuds off, and the heat levels here are authentic. I don't recommend exceeding their mildest level.

CtQuo3QVL3-Ig4B2Sj5p7w.text: Everything I have ever had here is delicious. The service is fast and friendly. They are almost always busy, busy the wait is with it. The cost to quality radio is amazing. I love the see yew and the kee mao. The spice level goes from one to five. I really like heat, and I usually get a level 4. They are BYOB and close to a liquor store. They don't have a phone, so any take out orders have to be made in person. They are cash only with an ATM on site. I would go there multiple times a week if I could

gSXNXiElRwmWumjH_2S-xA.text: Excellent Thai flavors.  My favorite: street noodle 1, with just the right cilantro and lime overtones.

rQetGr3vaQx-Nrs7GwTA4w.text: Delicious but a bit of a wait. Worth it though for noodles done perfectly. Make sure to Bring something to pair with dishes.

uboAllu4rr5Z-lA7Hu3_lg.text: A great noodle house with a simple menu. The best steamed pork buns that I've tried - tender meat, fresh cilantro and cucumber, and some unrecognizable sauce that's amazing. My favorite dish there is the Chiang Mai, but I tried the see yew last night. I didn't love it as much as the Chiang but it was still hot and delicious. Be careful with your spice level!!

wo_i3GyADSJLOoAzJzxt4w.text: This is just a few blocks from my place. Like tge decor. Nice service, quick and helpful. Small menus.  Food  is nice. If you don't wanna spend too much (About $6-$8) and have noodles for lunch - this is your place!

UXHfythkKAJDFkYnXfRDWw.text: Likely my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh.  The food is consistent and delicious. I'm not a fan of spicy food so there are a number of items I haven't tried.  The food is unique enough that if you eat the same thing every single time and you go there once a week for four months, you'll still want to go back.   Cash only!

kCGwMkCGnxd_WC4qTvQKyA.text: Inexpensive. Delicious. Highly recommended I truly felt the food is Thailand quality!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

VS95cm0VhffuDs28dGroQw.text: Wow what a wonderful place!!  The Sukhothai soup was to die for! Pork meatballs were delicious and broth was delicious. Fast service and great food!!

OXVH7P-eYh3-6XFneLF8Iw.text: This is a great new sport my husband and I went to randomly when everything else around had long waits.  The atmosphere was nice. Great design and theme but it was very cold and drafty every time the door opened.   We had the pig wings which were just okay. The sauce was good but overwhelming and it was really small considering they were two bucks a pop. Came with a homemade pickle salad that tasted like taking a shot of vinegar... I love anything picked and this was unbearable.  The Chiang mai curry was outstanding. Nice mix of coconut milk and spice. The noodles were crunchy on top and a nice way to soak up the coconut milk curry soup in the bowl. I got a spice level 2 and it was perfect, it was the right kick of heat without having me reach for a drink every bite.   My husband had the noodle #1 at a level 4 heat so I didn't even try... way too spicy for me. I did have the chicken on top which was not spiced and everyone's review is right-it's well with it for the amazing chicken. Chicken was nice and juicy and had a great crunchy coating.  This is a great spot to try something new. Not too expensive, byob with $5 fee per person. But it's cash only so be advised. They do have an ATM. I just think with all the apps out there they can get it together and accept cards... just a peeve of mine.

h8-HEsyUCV39dCggRsU0FQ.text: Best Pad Thai in all of Pittsburgh! For a place with no phone and no card abilities it's always hopping. They get you in and out fast, too.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Modern industrial design meets rustic decor with a wide variety of metal and repurposed wood accents.

aEm2OhRH8Kxt63L-JhriVg.text: Every city in the country needs a place like this - cheap, fast, great ambiance and extraordinarily delicious! Its like providing the authentic hole-in-the-wall food experience without being a hole-in-the-wall. We got the pork buns which came out way too fast - probably 2 mins after we placed our order and could have been warmer and/or fresher but it was all uphill from there. The sukothai and chang mai noodles were the right amount of spicy for us (3) and had so many amazing flavors! We loved this place.  Downside is they don't take credit cards but nothing should deter you from going here and trying it at least once and probably more!

fHqrYaZ9YHwmGppWMhUhUA.text: Small menu but big taste. Been here a couple times and it's becoming my go to noodle place. Great staff, excellent service and affordable food. Plus their BYOB policy has no corkage fee!

KymH9wACvn9m1bmRYhuoEw.text: Just got home from dinner at Noodlehead, and can't wait to go back! The Pig Wings are awesome!!!

xKkj6GmtprubUTaFFkofiA.text: The best Thai restaurant in Pittsburgh for me! Being a vegetarian finding good options is always a challenge but not here! The Pad Thai and Kee Mao with Tofu is absolutely delicious!  Noodlehead has a very nice atmosphere and the staff are very friendly. The service is also quick. The portions are large and it's really affordable.

76T9gJAMbLswchp6pz0Qvw.text: Hands down best noodles for the price in Pittsburgh. Great atmosphere, too. I hope Noodlehead sticks around for years to come!

9vVDH56V93HzaTNEN8oo7w.text: Pork Buns, Pork Buns, PORK BUNS!!!  The flavor in those thing's is unbelievable.  The atmosphere in this place, indescribable, the cost to eat here, more than affordable!  My good friend took me to lunch here for my birthday and I got the Crispy Chicken dish with noodles and that might of been the juiciest most flavorful chicken I had all of 2014 so far.  Oh yeah, The Pork Buns, don't even THINK about leaving this place if you don't order these.  Even if the thought of Pork Turns you off, these might Still hit the spot.  Another charming place with unique twists everywhere from the small menu to how they serve you water.  Look high class for a middle class price, my type of place!  Tell them HITTofMCM's sent ya!

we8UJsh5P5yehFHQe_rXuw.text: Noodlehead is one of my favorite places in Pittsburgh. The dishes are all pretty tasty, and everything is very reasonably priced. I typically handle a moderate amount of spiciness in my food, but I've found that when they ask you to select a spiciness for your dish, it's better to select conservatively, because they can be pretty serious about it! Other than that, just remember to have some cash on hand, and enjoy the menu.

7RAO0lIpuY7coYzxW_XVHQ.text: Love this place! The decor is cute and the atmosphere is quite nice. The staff are always friendly, not like in some of the trendier Shadyside places that try too hard to come off hip. (It's like they've forgotten the fact that they live in Pennsylvania!) The menu is simple, and the spice levels and in some cases types of meat can be customized. Everything here is somewhat spicy but not obnoxiously so unless requested. It's cash only, but there is an ATM on the premises. Since plenty of places in Pittsburgh seem to be that way, it's a feature of dining here that I've finally become used to.

FpQwbH5eC18NAKr--yxJuQ.text: Tried street #2 and the crispy spring roll, the noodle was good but the spring roll so so. The restaurant is worth a try though.

0S3Pt5YhUCTpOHxHYI1pSQ.text: "FEATURING TASTY NOODLE DISHES FROM THE STREET MARKETS OF THAILAND!"  is what Noodlehead's website blazes.  Had a Friday evening dinner recently with a group of 6 to celebrate one of who had been visiting and working with us  for six months from Thailand.  She is returning to Thailand next week.  We were surprised when she wanted Thai food for her farewell dinner back to Thailand, but later she told us this food tastes nothing like the street food in Thailand (so much for the website claim).  However, if it's good enough for someone from Thailand to choose it for a farewell dinner, it's probably pretty good.  Parking is absolutely terrible around this area of Highland Ave.  At least it's relatively safe as you're walking to your car 4 blocks away.  Arriving at 5:40pm, the  small space (seats about 50 by my estimation) was already completely full.  Pittsburghers do like to eat early.  Noodlehead has an annoying but well documented policy that they won't seat you until your entire group is present.  Although some of our group members were late, there wasn't anywhere for us to sit until 30 minutes anyway.  Noodlehead is BYOB (50 cents/person corkage), so no drinks while you're waiting (and this is not the kind of place that will call you while you grab a drink down the street).  The menu is basic American-Thai fare.  There's just a few appetizers like pork belly steamed buns and Thai fried chicken.  There's a variety of noodle dishes like Pad Thai and "Street Noodle."  As other's have mentioned, for most of the dishes you pick a spice level from 1 to 5.  1 is clear your sinuses, slightly runny nose hot so be very careful unless you're used to this kind of thing (our Thai friend ordered a 5).  You'll have a better meal and avoid next-day unpleasantness.    Everything was tasty, but no better or worse than any other Thai place that I've been to in Pittsburgh.    The service was fast and friendly.  By the time we got up to leave, the crowd waiting was staggering.  More people were waiting than there were seats in the restaurant.  Noodlehead's good, but with the hideous parking situation, the long wait for a table, and the overall standard cuisine, I don't understand the popularity of this particular establishment.

LrfFgKWybP6q8czhbhpOhA.text: I have probably been here about 5 times over the past few years, the most recent time being this past weekend. I was really impressed on my first visit by the interior of the restaurant. It's very unique and still looks as though it just recently opened.  The menu is fairly straightforward. I appreciate places that keep things simple, as opposed having menus that are the length of a short book. Variety is good, but you have to draw the line somewhere!  The pork belly steamed buns are an absolute must. Tender shredded pork topped with a small amount of pickled cucumber that adds a nice texture and flavor. The buns themselves are fluffy and delicious. You get two in a serving... don't split this with anyone because you will DEFINITELY want more than one. I don't want to even think about how many of these I could probably eat if given the challenge.  I've had a few noodle dishes and enjoyed them all, but on my most recent trip I had the pad thai with chicken. They take spice pretty seriously here, so I ordered a two out of five. I could have probably gone to a three but it was still fairly spicy. The portion was also pretty generous and I ended up taking leftovers for lunch the next day.  The only downside, as many have mentioned, is that they don't take credit cards. Kind of annoying as I am one of those people who rarely carries much cash, but it's worth it for this place.

61x909Dfne6bOIrkH5HF1Q.text: Even though mi amigo and I had just enjoyed a taco dinner, I urged him to try a pork bun here! Sure enough, anything you put in a heavenly white bun tastes amazing, and noodlehouses pork & pickled cukes were very satisfying! I also loved the lemongrass tea and overall vibe.  Next time I'm in PA I will be back!

fHPlIvtoXsKrr1vOchKAXw.text: Food is always good here, I've never had to complain! You HAVE to get their steamed pork buns or you've just wasted your trip!!

LFNs7x5OWuIMHBKeNAU2lQ.text: This place is the Platonic Form of comfort food.  Noodlehead is my neighborhood noodle joint and I want to eat it all the time.  The restaurant is a little too precious for its own good in some ways-- they don't take credit cards and they don't have a phone??--but the food is so yum that I forgive them.  It's BYOB and almost all the noodle dishes are $9, so it's a super inexpensive date night, if you can get a table.  I still really wish they'd offer me a telephone number so I could call ahead for takeout.   So on to the food.  The pork steamed buns are a must-try appetizer.  I often threaten to go there and just get multiple orders of these for dinner, but it hasn't happened just yet.  My favorite noodles are the pad see yew--sweet, tangy, and good balance of ingredients.  The green curry linguini is great, though I wish it had some veggies. Note that everything is quite spicy, so a 3 out of 5 spice is more akin to a 7/8 out of 10 at a lot of other Thai places.     There is nothing disappointing on the menu.  One of the best values around, for sure.

kss2JqTSIzrdTVRdeccXFg.text: I really enjoyed this restaurant. Very simple menu and affordable prices. The street noodles were tasty and had just enough heat. The curry noodles were even better as left overs the next day. Waiters were attentive and helpful.

pQOVV4acLVk7qYLi4c9bCw.text: The steamed pork belly buns are a must. I also had the love boat with a spice level of three and it was delicious. The menu features fresh foods and the atmosphere is welcoming. The service is quick, but manages to not make you feel rushed.  The menu is short, which I love. A lot of restaurants have way too many options... But I appreciate it when I don't have to take 20 minutes to read over the menu. It can be very overwhelming sometimes to have to choose between a significant amount of menu items.  It's BYOB which is also another plus. I'm a poor college student so finding byob places helps to not break the bank.

IaclB7J7wtZhgvARC8sdCQ.text: If you've been frustrated by the other dreadful "Thai" restaurants in Pittsburgh, you'll be EXTREMELY pleased with Noodlehead. They actually know what Thai spicy really is! I searched for a "while" (specifically I've been to Nicky's Thai, Smiling Banana Leaf, Thai Cuisine on Liberty Ave, Silk Elephant), and none of those compare.  I've had 4 dishes here: Pad Thai, Chiang Mai Curry, See Yew and Pork buns.  Btw, Silk Elephant is also "OK" Thai, but if you are torn between the two, go to Noodlehead. As a side-point I also HIGHLY recommend Pusadee's Garden in Lawrenceville. It's BYOB and Thai spicy/flavorful also, but isn't cash only and, oh yea they actually have a phone number :-) The downside is they are a bit more expensive.... So if you're ballin' choose the Garden.

j6-4JfcU3hPnXtCZuh2FaQ.text: Best place in town. Make sure to budget some time to wait for a seat during prime time.  Bring a bottle of wine it's BYOB! Everything on the menu is fantastic! I wish they had a phone number so I could order to go more easily.

rSfSqTVATAiadgMDKIiX2w.text: Really delicious food here. The staff is pretty nice and I definitely will visit again!  The only bad this is its cash only. They have an ATM but that can sometimes be an inconvenience.

0nrANbZ8NUyHRqpi-7M9Rw.text: Let me tell you how hard it was for me to visit this place.  It's not to complain, just to show how forgetful I am.  I love the stretch of Highland that Noodlehead sits on.  There is so much life on this small strip that the sidewalks become congested rather easily and parking is horrendous, but that doesn't stop people from lining up to get in here.  Another reason I had been avoiding coming here was my new found allergy to peanuts.  Not knowing how this allergy could be set off I decided to steer clear of here until I had properly addressed this.  Once I had my ducks in a row all I needed to do was remember to bring CASH.  I rarely carry cash on myself, becoming a follower of the technology movement.  This time I had made plans ahead of time to visit here and stopped to get myself some cash.  Cash in hand I headed to Noodlehead.  The inside is very welcoming.  It feels very open and almost natural inside.  You are greeted promptly, when I was here we were told to take a seat wherever we please, we had picked a time before the line starts to form outside, so lucky for us the place wasn't crowded.  My companion I was with had raved about how good the food was so I leaned on him for suggestions.  He had been here multiple times and knew his way around the menu.  We had started our meal with Pork Belly Steam Buns.  For something so little it was packed with a lot of flavor.  So savory that I wished I had just ordered a multitude of those as my main meal.  It was one of those food that you just wanted to suck all the flavor out of until your tongue wrapped around that pork belly and you made sure every single taste bud got a sample of that flavor.  My mouth is watering thinking about it right now.  I was happy to see that water was brought fresh to every table upon being seated.  But I was also happy to see that they had sodas on the menu that I could actually drink.  Whenever a restaurant has Sprite from Mexico on the menu they always get bonus points in my book.  For my main course I had decided I would give the Beef Soup a try.  I was a little puzzled when I was asked what level of spice I wanted.  Not knowing for sure I deferred to my companion and thought that the suggestion to get it at a low level but have more brought out with my meal in case I wanted to up the heat was a brilliant idea.  The mixture of the fresh vegetables and perfectly cooked beef was the best.  The thin rice noodles were to die for.  But I loved the bean sprouts and bok choy the most.  They added a crunch to this dish that made it feel a little more like a meal rather than a soup.  Unfortunately for me, I could not devour this big bowl of soup.  I was so full after about half that I had to stop eating.  The staff in here were great.  They were so friendly and knowledgeable about the menu/establishment.  Might I also say that they were fast as hell?  My god, maybe it was the time we were there, but they were lightning fast.  Everything we ordered showed up in no time flat.    This place is definitely a reason for me to carry cash around.  **ATM on site (found this out afterwards), BYOB**

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef soup.

wHYPcUqIbm3D5oR_Xq-hcA.text: Drove through Pittsburgh during a road trip and decided to grab food here due to wonderful reviews. Went during lunchtime on a Saturday, it was pretty busy so there was a 20 minute wait. Also its downtown so its street parking, no private lot. I got the pad thai, street noodle #1 and pork belly steamed buns. There pork buns were delicious, it tasted tangy and sweet with a very authentic taste. 2 was not nearly enough! The Pad Thai portion however was huge, way too much noodle, I was full after a quarter of the way through with a lot of leftovers which I boxed for later. The chicken in the street noodle #1 dish was so crispy and juicy. I loved it. Definitely a specialty dish that you cannot find at other Thai restaurants which is what makes this place so unique and great. I highly recommend this if you're in the area.

Pr8LCIYlRtDhl4-YjWEJNQ.text: 4.5 stars. The food was AMAZING. The waiter was sweet and the price was unbeatable. My only complaint was the accuracy of my order. We got shrimp instead of chicken and our spicy numbers should have been the same but were drastically different. Didn't disappoint though.

seIWbvvctGH2ic5yvP7wsg.text: I came here quite often and their noodles are really great! The finger foods are great too! I love the pulled-pork steamed buns! So great! And the fried chicken is really tasty and not so greasy! But it was my first to try the pork dumplings this time...ughhh not so good, I thought it would taste like siu-mai, but it's not even close...but other than that, everything is great!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried chicken
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork dumplings (just okay..)
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pulled-pork steamed bun

se2D4SMRFc0HqTqjteGyVw.text: Noodlehead is probably my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. This blows my mind because it is also one of the most budget-friendly restaurants.  I have been here at least 10 times, if not more. The service and food are consistently amazing. Their broth is extremely flavorful, they keep the tables and environment spotless and well decorated, and they have never failed to have fresh plants on display, which I appreciate in the winter.  Winning Dishes Are: The Loveboat and Pork Buns.  This is the perfect spot to take someone new to Pittsburgh if you want to impress them with our cuisine!

8SAaFOCnC1dq5uUtYnRJww.text: Great place! We live a block away so we're here often.  I love the no nonsense noodle house culture that makes service fast and familiar, yet the flavors are layered and complex. Favorite dishes include...everything on the menu! I'm vegan so I get everything with tofu or just the vegetables but before I was vegan, the beef Pho-like soup was my go to.  Cash only but there's an atm in the back.

FPFvVCznnkzscmRPSy5c6Q.text: I frequent Noodlehead and I am never disappointed. Quaint atmosphere, very hipster like. I love the idea of cash only and it's nice that they have an ATM on site. Only complaint is that you need to be careful when selecting the spice level, otherwise it is fantastic!

z6EC1fscHG1qey5uz1qKog.text: Definitely one of the best Thai restaurants in Pittsburgh. If you look in the kitchen you will see all Thai chefs, which is a really good sign. The food here tastes as authentic as when I ate it during my visit to Thailand. Be careful with the spice levels here as a 5/5 can sometimes nearly kill you, and other times be not spicy enough.  Anytime a friend visits from out of town, this is usually the first place I recommend. Super cheap and delicious.

HQrBer-eRd3vdELX0cm31g.text: Cute space! Love the pork buns, but the Pad Thai was a little bit oily for me. Next time may try other noodles. Btw the service was good!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

J8PZfLqdcc2ndZr-zOlGhw.text: Perfection. The dishes are creative , good sized, and well cooked. Our server was informative and attentive (and rocked the most awesome silver blonde locks). It's always busy there but wait time is short. I wish they had more outdoor tables. Can't wait to go back

iIm7rNaCDQPwr2YlPaPlHA.text: Really surprised by how good this place is. Great selection of dishes, most are unique. Essentially it's a twist of regular Thai food where they put noodles in some curries instead of serving it with rice. I have only tried one of the two curries offered and it was very flavorful and really good. They have a lot of other dishes that I am looking forward to try. The dishes are pretty cheap and the restaurant is very quick with service! Our dishes came out in 3 mins. Will be coming back to try other dishes. They also have random mexican drinks on the menu for some reason. Great restaurant!

Leeuioxpbv6uAPnlKFvoWQ.text: We got there 15 min after it opened and there was already a wait. This place is so popular but they move people through quickly. Cash only and byob so come prepared!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green curry with shrimp

efymp1U3JnUsNYQQltVBnQ.text: One of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh. In the heart of Pittsburgh's yuppie district (Shadyside), this place is always full to the brim. You'll be waiting for at least 15-20 minutes if you come for dinner on a Friday or Saturday night, but there's plenty to do (drink) right around the corner while you're waiting. You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu, and this place works wells for vegetarians as well. Can't wait for my next trip back!

FghNCHLxdaSesLjvhh2dkQ.text: the first and i hope last time bad experience with Noodlehead,  it's all server! She was blonde and short hair! Idk the name. It was 12th August Sunday night  first thing she said to me was "what do you want to order ?"  i'm like "hiii, ..."  and i placed an order, they brought me spring rolls they were good, and then she brings me Kee Mao wt shrimp, i ordered it wt chicken, and she tried to convince me i said shrimp, i never get shrimp wt noodles, i didn't even know it was an option, she gives me face takes it back, brings the one wt chicken, i always get spice level 2 and it's perfect for me this one was sooo spicy, my mouth is still burning from it, i only had one bite of my food and she brought me a box and my check,  she didn't ask if i liked my food, if i actually wanted a box ... nothing... it's crazy

o9kk_ARNdzLNHXB7pBx3CQ.text: Noodlehead is an excellent place to go for casual thai noodles. The servings are generous for the price, and the flavor is great! For the spice lovers, pick spiciness levels 3 and up. The only caveat is that it is cash only, so bring some! (They have an atm there as well)

FEOVMgyqBv-7lSm3mwK2ag.text: Noodlehead shook me up man.  So I came here every week in college basically with my good friend after our intro piano class which was hard as rocks, and noodlehead's atmosphere is just the perfect place to let off that school/work/life angst and just have a good time with good people. It really is. BYO-drinks is the best part of that and it's always buzzing with good energy.   WELL when I went back a year and a half later I got two things: the Chang mai curry and the pad see yew.   The pad see yew was always my usual and I love it here because it is such a classic Thai dish but sometimes I feel like I have to add to it with sriracha. And I love sriracha so sometimes I go over board and over power my food with it, but I like that, you know? Not this one tho. The flavors of the dish are so good that I don't even wanna touch it. Spicy level 2 is perfect for me to keep the heat at a good kick but at the same time, not burn your buds off so you can't taste the flavor .. or the worst - when u have to wait for the dish to cool down in temperature because that adds to the heat and depletes the flavor.   Now THE CHANG MAI CURRY THO -  First time trying. As I was eating this I was thinking in my head, "when can I fit in my schedule to come back here and have this again". That's when you know it's incredible. It's the best Asian curry I have ever had. I think the restaurant could stand alone on this dish - it's not just the fact that it has great texture play with the egg noodles and the crunchy noodle garnish top, but the curry itself was out of this world. So much so that I kept JUST taking spoonfuls of it and letting the flavors sink into my taste buds. Same spice comments as mentioned above.   Last note - momofuku's David Chang says that the best places to eat sometimes are the ones that don't have exceptional service. Now, I've never had a problem with noodle heads service, ever. But this time around we waited around 20 minutes before someone came to our table. But the food was SO good that it didn't even matter at the end. Like I could not have left that place in any other mood but on cloud 9  PLEASE GO TO NOODLE HEAD  Also it's cash only with atm in the back.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

KS9Kk6aJHO2jUcjpfbJZrg.text: No reservation, CASH, often crowded but worth it for them tasty noodles. If you like your Thai food with a kick or flavor, would not recommend the "street noodle 1" dish. Just doesn't taste as exciting as it sounds. BUT everything else I have tried has been scrummy. 50c BYO fee can't be beat.

lkDyEpK6VQFIp8nnkuKX6w.text: This has been one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh before being vegan and during.  There's a note on a board that says NO SUBSTITUTIONS.  Which I understand but we've asked if things could be made vegan and the staff has always been accommodating except the last time we were there.  My partner and I both suffered from food poisoning after our meal and I can only assume the food was poisoned because we requested vegan.  It's a shame, we'll never be returning.

7BATKZrppot9Z6MAks2fvQ.text: Food is insanely good but the fact that is is cash only is a complete buzzkill. It's 2018 people... the world uses debit and credit cards. Please make life more convenient for your customers.

oYlS1tjb9ngtT1YfakPk-w.text: Good, but the cash only thing is dodgy and unnecessary in 2019. My kids love their noodles and the price is VERY fair.

vtQzCY3Tlx66ZX3mS610_A.text: This place is a True gem in Shadyside. I was fortunate to have gone on the tail end of the dinner rush and was seated within 5 minutes.   We ordered way too much food for just two people, but the menu has so many great dishes it's hard not to want to try them all. We ended up getting: the love boat, the pork baos, pad Thai, pad see ew, and the curry noodles. (There were a lot of leftovers). Everything was so delicious it's hard to go wrong with any choice. I would say my personal favorite was the pad see ew, and my boyfriend's favorite was the love boat. The only thing I would have to say is misleading is the spice level-- the dishes weren't as spicy as I was expecting them to be!   The service was fantastic the whole night and it was just a great atmosphere to dine on a Friday night. Will be back again!

9q1MkP2r1TG8arxjAi_y-g.text: Personally, felt that the place had a snobby atmosphere to it but also maybe I was being extra judgemental because it claims to serve "Thai" food.  Food was good but definitely not "Thai". If you're looking for authentic flavors, I'd look else where. A lot of the ingredients used in the dishes are adapted and improvised. The Love Boat tasted nothing like a traditional Thai Boat Noodle, but it was edible.   I tried my friend's Chiang Mai Curry which I think is their version of Khao Soi and it was super sweet even when my friend asked for the Level 4 hotness.   Overall, not too impressed. Prices might be good for the area and their portion but don't think I'd really recommend this place to anyone who's looking for good Thai food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Love Boat

gJ5U_tC1mWoC8M89UgFf8g.text: I've never dined in because so busy but takeout is the bomb  Lots of things can be vegan or glutenfree

RfHoGWfRtQpV2prqdUMCrQ.text: Noodlehead reminds a little of the Midwest,hipster, small restaurant feel mixed with an east coast busyness and clamor. Loved the atmosphere and decor, it appears to be a nice casual date place. Noodlehead must be a local rage because there was a line from the time we got here, waited (30 minutes) and when we left. They have a small menu but everything looked so good. BYOB policy with a very minor 50 cents recycling fee per person. Service was excellent. They have an arrangement of regular low tables inside, and high tables that face the street. Menu prices are extremely reasonable for the portions, none above $9.50. We got the pig wing appetizer, and because I am indecisive, I got (aka forced) my husband to share two different noodle dishes.   The Chang mai curry noodles was a bowl of abundant noodles with chicken in a rich yellow curry sauce, thick with coconut cream. The generous portion of chicken was cooked to perfection - tender but moist. The dish included some fried noodles on top, which gave it a great extra texture. It could use vegetables or lime to lighten and brighten it up, but that being said I ate every last morsel that was in this bowl. Clearly I was not so offended by the lack of veggies.  The second dish was a noodle soup - the loveboat. This bowl of vermicelli noodles came with chopped bok and some tender beef slices. The soup came with basil and seemed to have a hint of lemongrass. It's unique in that it is both savory and slightly sweet. The basil definitely added to the meaty-ness of the beef. Noodles were abundant and cooked just right. We love spicy food but we ordered both dishes medium in heat, because the worst thing a restaurant could do is overspice the food that you can't taste anything but heat! I would say the loveboat is definitely slightly spicier than the Chang mai noodle dish, as the coconut cream tempered the spiciness.  The only minor gripe I had was the appetizer, which was the pig wings. This plate came with what appeared three spareribs, decent in portion, and slightly fried before tossed in the sauce. Texture was tender on the inside and slightly crunchy on the outside. The sauce was somewhat reminiscent of teriyaki but was slightly too salty. Mind you I was salivating while writing this review of my yesterday night dinner, so everything was decently good. If I had to redo the experience, the only thing I would change would be to possibly try another appetizer.  Verdict: If i could give a 4.75 stars with the little ding for the appetizer, i would. That being said we loved this establishment and the food despite the wait. We didn't have enough time to try the ice cream parlors next door but many people seemed to have checked them out while waiting.  Oh yeah if you haven't read the hundreds of reviews notifying you it is cash only, then that ones on you!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pig wings
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chang mai curry noodles $9.50
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Loveboat (beef noodle soup)

tgyrl17AWcnJbk5cBwHXow.text: I loved Noodlehead! I had the Chiang Mai noodles and it was one of the best I've had stateside.   The noodles come out super quickly. The portions are quite large as well. The crispy chicken in the street noodle #1 was quite good, although the sauce was a little sweet and not as balanced as I would've hoped.   The lemongrass honey iced tea was refreshing and great with the meal as well. They also give you one refill!   I thought that Noodlehead was more of a take-out, hole-in-the-wall but I was pleasantly surprised that the ambiance was so chic + modern.   All of the noodles are $9.50 which is such a great price!! You shouldn't miss Noodlehead, it lives up to expectations.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. #1 street noodle
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai style

BUq8oh0so0IJFaHqqhGU3w.text: Husband and I visited around 2pm (Friday) and it was super busy!  I will admit, our initial impression of this place was NOT positive. The restaurant was really dark and relatively small, and the person at the counter was a bit indifferent.  We sat at the tabletop seats (where it was the brightest) and it took a while for our waitress to notice we were ready to order.  We ordered a Sukothai noodle (spicy level 4: Thai hot), Street noodle #1 (spicy level: medium), and spring rolls.  You can choose your spicy level (not hot ~ crazy hot).   The food was SOOOOOO DELICIOUS. The portion size was perfect, everything was flavorful, and the ingredients were fresh. The food here definitely tastes more authentic Asian; no shying away from strong herbs and spices. It reminded me of my trips to Southeast Asia.  Although the service wasn't the best, the food ABSOLUTELY made up for it!!!! Strongly recommend!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodle #1 (spicy level: medium)
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sukothai (spicy level: Thai hot)

tiMWfj1ejwiv5KiTg5Wbuw.text: Review is just got a to-go order! We weren't really hungry but knew we'll need something for dinner since the last time we ate was around 1pm. We went to Millie's Ice Cream and then decided to stop by Noodlehead to pick some stuff up before taking an Uber back to our hotel. Boy was this place busy on a Friday evening! There were so many people waiting outside! It wasn't as bad after the Millie's run but we opted to place an order anyway. It's cash only and good luck trying to place an order with such a small hostess area. People were coming and going constantly! We placed our order and was quoted a 20 min wait for our food! It came out in due time! We ate when we got home and the food was pretty good! The Green Curry Fettuccine had awesome flavors and lots of veggies! It's sweet due to the coconut milk in the curry, and was very creamy! We enjoyed it a lot 4/5.  We also ordered the See Eww Noodles, which were also delicious in flavors! I thought it needed a bit of smokiness to the noodles so they weren't so wet. I almost felt like it was a bit too soft without the crisp to the noodles and the tofu. But I liked it nonetheless. Portions are a normal decent size. I would love to come back and dine in next time to try some of the other dishes! Interior looked cute and modern! Good place for date night! ___________  Actually came back for dinner the next night cause it's been some of the best food we've had during our short stay in Pittsburgh. We decided to come for a dine-in experience and expected a wait cause of how busy it was the previous night. The lady said about 20-25 mins, not horrible for a Saturday night. What I was disappointed with was that other parties that obviously came after us were seated before us. And I don't mean parties of 2, cause I knew those tables opened up quicker than larger tables for 4.. but I literally checked in with the hostess and other parties of 4 or 5 got crossed off the list before me and their names were after mine. Wtf?! There was no rhyme or reason to their madness.. then after we sat down and ordered, the table of 5 and another table of 4, that was seated after us got their food before us! Again.. wtf?! How were the tickets entered?! I felt like we were being discriminated against - I mean, what are the odds that most of the Caucasian groups were seated and got their food before us?! Especially if they were seated after us?! Or arrived after us?! This place doesn't take reservations and is a first come, first serve restaurant so I can't think of any other possible explanations. Besides that, the food was again spot on at a very reasonable price. The See Eww Noodles has delicious flavors and we had nothing to complain about. The pork dumplings weren't anything special but the noodles.. get them, you won't be disappointed.  I lowered the star rating because of the horrible wait and service - we literally ended up waiting about 1.5 hrs total to be seated and for our food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Exterior as we wait for our to-go order!
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green Curry Fettuccine with Chicken to-go

doUdw9F79wCGn24TtokuPg.text: MUST NOTE: Cash only!   Now that that's out of the way (and it wasn't a problem for us), the review: my friend insisted we go here upon my visit to him him in Pittsburgh, as he'd said this is the best Thai in the city. While my sample size currently sits at an "n" of 1, I don't see a reason to disagree. I had an excellent pad kee mao dish with extra chicken. The sauce in particular had incredible flavor.   It was also quite affordable - I think after the addition of extra chicken, it was still in the $11-$13 range. I wish I could go back for more; I'll just have to visit Pittsburgh again soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Kee Mao

0TbhiLBs7ZoPfLHzbPJPaw.text: We came here upon recommendation from a friend. This place is always busy every time we walked by.  The only downside is that it is cash only, so make sure you have cash on you.  We ordered the green curry linguine at a Thai hot level and it was delicious. Would definitely recommend it if you are craving some Thai food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green curry linguine

gDxVrj4ashkYbsKKO32FLw.text: Loved this place! Good space and sitting distribution. It was very full yet it was comfortable. I ordered the beef noodle soup and my friends ordered pad thai and street noodles with chicken. The service was quick and the portions were generous. The spice level was appropriate. Level 3 spice is good for spicy lovers. Level 5 is really hot but its tasty too. Overall a great place. The only caveat is that it is cash only.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodles 1
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad thai
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef noodle soup

SvN-o_ahUlS5lf2f9LyjmA.text: Duh, the best place for Thai eats in the city. Cheap, limited menu (for the better at a place like this), BYOB, and in a rocking trendy spot.   Pork buns and chiang Mai Curry chicken are a must.   The love boat soup is always a classic as well.  I will always love this place and it's great for just about any occasion. Only complaint is that it's cash only, but hey.. Can you blame them?

0Ds9rPCpb07X0u0tHEcdAA.text: Love the food here. Priced reasonably and large portion to satisfy. It's always a busy place but we got lucky today and walked right in. Server was super quick to get our orders and remained in contact with us throughout dine. Great service!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef Soup
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef Soup

NaHb8MRZKmFF_meardbcfg.text: I came here on a Friday at around 7:30pm with a friend and we were told we'd have to wait 30-45 minutes. Noodlehead is BYOB with a $0.50 recycling fee per person, so we brought along a bottle of wine. The hostess opened the bottle for us and provided us with glasses so we could drink while we waited! We ended up being seated after about 20 minutes.   We shared the Street Noodle 1 and Chiang Mai Curry (both were $9.50) and they were both amazing! The fried chicken in the Street Noodle 1 wasn't too bready and felt freshly fried. The saltiness of it with the slight sweetness of the sauce and noodles were divine. The curry in the Chiang Mai Curry was simply freaking delicious. Pour some of it over the crunchy noodles and you have yourself a piece of paradise. My mouth is watering just thinking about them!   I was just the right amount of full when we finished eating. For the price, the size and flavor are well worth it! I will most definitely come back again next time I'm in Pittsburgh and wish this restaurant was in my city instead!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Curry
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street Noodle 1

MJcfjrJAlt6VdfMzEJngLw.text: Absolutely amazing place for the price. We routinely go here and have Street Noodle #1 and See Yew. Those two are my favorite. Don't forget that their "spicy level" is real. I like spicy food so much more than my friends but I only tried up to level 3. Level 2 is just good for me.

HLoq7u8jfU83vEBgKL3dkQ.text: *HIGLY RECOMMEND*  Noodlehead is a great cheap eats place in Pittsburgh. All the items on the menu are under $10 and you get a very filling portion.
