They have many vegetarian options, and it's super yummy.  Parking is not ideal, it's in the city.. so plan to park on the street. Also, super small dark space which is nice and trendy but can get pretty crowded in the evenings!  Would recommend Noodlehead to anyone looking to have some good, and cheap food! Also, I always love BYOB restaurants, a $7 bottle of wine for dinner makes all the difference!

tS5qvwPBN6DZIEM6e5yzrA.text: Noodlehead is a great spot! I have loved every meal I have tried, especially the pork steamed buns, the beef soup, and the love boat. The beef is always tender and delicious. The spice levels go from 0-5.  Experienced spice eaters only above level 3!    Noodlehead does not take reservations, so be prepared to wait during peak times. They are BYOB, and only charge a small recycling fee. I suggest bring wine to drink while you wait - I've waited an hour before (the food is that good)! They also don't have a phone, so you need to go in to order takeout. They are cash only, but do have an ATM. Their prices are all below $10!  Only negative would be that I have experienced mixed service during my visits at Noodlehead. Most servers are great, but I've found that a few are less than friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

msjk7jbqcQPoZHVvAykxVw.text: I went to this place for lunch on my day off because I was in the area and it did not disappoint! I got the Shrimp Kee Mao with Medium spice level and sat at the window for lunch. The dish was great, and definitely spicy for being a level 2, so be wary of that. The device was very nice and the space itself had a cool atmosphere. Was a bit dark, if that bothers anyone, which it personally doesn't. Overall, I am coming back again and bringing friends so they can experience this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp Kee Mao

3-5qs1NNFwcQ8aRa2tiygw.text: Overall, Noodlehead is a solid choice if you want fast, Thai food. Given that there isn't a long wait.  I have gotten Kee Mao, Pad Thai, and See You ($9.5). These 3 are all good, but be particular when choosing your spice level. I usually get at least a 3/5 but my most recent time I got a 1/5 and it was a lot spicier than I was expecting. With the growing popularity of this place, serving size has definitely gone down while they increased their prices.  Noodlehead is a decent, hipster Thai spot to go for a fun night out or a date but I hope you weren't expecting to have a conversation here, it can get loud. Cash only and its BYOB. (No byob if you're going to sit outside though.)

iJcG2OyPEyFBU6ViKKw1_g.text: I've been going to Noodlhead for a few years now, and have always had an enjoyable experience. It's a great mix of quality and affordable. Great for dates or taking the parents out to dinner when they're in town.   I ordered the green curry linguine and was satisfied. I would have preferred the sauce to be a little more thick, but it wasn't a huge impact. I thought the amount of noodles given was fine, but would have preferred a slightly larger portion.   pros -cheap -quick -everything I've ordered here tastes great (pad see yew, street noodle #1, green curry linguine)   cons -spice is just heat - not much flavor to it (and their scale is pretty drastic. Don't order a 4 or higher unless you really like heat) -this place is cash only -it is extremely busy during peak business hours and you can wait ~1 hour for a table

CmOOj397EI64WV8l6i0O0Q.text: Amazing place! Best Pad Thai ever. But you should be careful for your spice level since we got only 2 but it was very very spicy.

PVnxh9WW__UerY91av29DQ.text: The food is really cheap. It's a decent deal if you are able to overlook the awful attitude of the hostesses. They usually have a list of people waiting so they power-trip and can be extremely rude. Not the first time this has happened by the way. I'm never going back.  We then went to another restaurant nearby, where they treat people like people and I appreciated that.

lvu7UEt3C-cttzAvNSPhjA.text: I like this place. The things I liked are the vibe, the relaxed laidback atmosphere. It is BYOB so no drinks. They primarily focus on food and I tried only one dish. Taste wise it didn't seem very different to me from regular Thai food. It's not expensive and sometimes there's a long wait but tables generally clear quickly that is not a leisurely spot. Place has charm and all of it together makes it fun.

sIZ30D2LgPrgAxNt2bBHSw.text: Stopped in here during our visit to Pittsburgh. Nice trendy little hipster spot. Keep in mind there is only street parking and they will not let you sit until the entire party arrives. Also they only accept cash, but there is an ATM on site. We arrived around 3PM and the place was popping. I can only imagine they are super packed during prime lunch/dinner hours.   Overall the food and flavors were delicious. Starting with apps, I did not enjoy the pork dumplings (too much of a mushy texture for me) or the pulled pork sandwich. That being said, my nephew loves the pork sandwich. I think, due to appearance I though they would taste like sui mai and Peking duck, very much not the case.  For entrees we ordered the below:  Chiang Mai Curry: loved the curry, but the noodles were a little tough. Saved the curry and had it over rice for leftovers at home. Yum!   Green Curry Linguini: absolutely delicious flavor with a little kick. Again, saved the curry sauce and had it again with rice at home ;) so good.   Beef soup: good flavor, tender pieces of beef.  Street Noodles: nothing to write home about.   Pad Sew Ew: YUUUUMMMM!!! Best dish we had.

atEgQyaV07XNZCMlV90Guw.text: I'll preface this review by stating that I have notoriously bad luck at trying whatever the go-to place is for a city I'm visiting. We came right at opening and had no trouble finding a seat. By the end of our meal the restaurant was crowded, which led to our waitress being a bit absent. We tried the steamed pork dumplings which were quite unappetizing. The pork seemed to be ground way too finely, so the filling tasted gummy and chewy. The street noodle 1 had a deliciously crispy fried chicken on top, but other than that tasted mostly of tamarind (or another similar flavor). The pad thai was extremely oily and mostly tasted like char. The dishes were all very one-note.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street Noodle 1
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steamed Pork Dumplings

9wXIOPqPKyQC_XKVV01wsA.text: EXCELLENT! First word that comes to mind when I think of Noodlehead. Fantastic food, awesome atmosphere and superb service. I couldn't have asked for a better experience my second time coming. Oddly enough, we sat in the same exact hi-top as the first time we visited. The results were the same if not better.   The pork dumplings were served what seemed like seconds after we ordered and were hot and steamy. Order one of the noodles (Pad Thai is everyone's favorite but I suggest See Yew). The spicy meter is spot on (1-5, 5 being the spiciest).   Best part about Noodlehead, BYOB and no corkage fee!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

BQ59v6FJEoY9FHOv_Vyz9g.text: Generous portions, fast service, and yummy food! Will definitely stop by again when I'm in Pittsburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yummy!!!
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Little sweet potato triangles!

v8j9uz0mvdmZpgGj6sHaEg.text: I really enjoy the food and experience here. I came with a friend who had a shellfish allergy and they were very helpful with letting him know exactly what he could order. I also appreciate the spiciness customization. I can't handle very spicy food and the 0 level was perfect for me! Just don't forget to bring cash or your atm card as they are cash only. I will be back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

uAYGhD1dbJCOTUEcQSEi0w.text: I've been hearing the hype about Noodlehead for probably the past 5 years and finally had the chance to experience it for myself. It did not disappoint! I always get nervous when places don't take reservations (I have been known to get pretty hangry while waiting), and when we arrived, it was a 40 minute wait so not terribly long and definitely worth waiting for. But so many people ahead of us wound up leaving/not being present when their name was called, so we only waited like 10 mins! So pro tip - hang around the restaurant while you are waiting to be called! For eats, I ordered the See Yew with tofu (spice level 0) and my boyfriend went for the Street Noodle #1 (spice level 1) per highly rated Yelp reviews - we both loved our dishes! I loved the wide noodles and the broccoli in the dish, and the sweet black soy sauce was the perfect binder for all the flavors. I hate over-sauced dishes, so I was pleasantly surprised with the level of sauce on my See Yew. My boyfriend was definitely surprised by the flavors of his dish, but in a good way! The citrus flavor paired nicely with the crispy chicken, and the thinner noodles were the best vesicle to capture all the flavors. Of note, he ordered his as a level 1 spice, and it definitely had a kick - just be aware that they bring the spice! Normally we get an app, but I didn't notice the "snack" section on the back of the menu - perhaps would be better placed above the main dishes? But no big, we were more than full from our meal. Also love that it's BYOB AND they only charge 50 cents for corkage - more places should take after in PGH! Overall, Noodlehead is a great staple in the PGH restaurant scene, and we will definitely stop by again on future visits to the city :)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Interior
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. See Yew

GCxjTCWtXlrNPkDEFo9VTQ.text: I have to say yelp never steers you wrong. Noodlehead has great reviews on Yelp, and they aren't wrong. We had lunch here today after touring the University of Pittsburgh. The ambiance is cool and hip. The service is great and the food is delicious. All for a great price.  So I read other reviews that recommend the love boat soup. It was a cold and raining so soup hit the spot. The soup was so delicious. I had the level 2 spice and it wasn't very spicy. The girls had level zero. We also shared spring rolls and pork dumplings. They to were delicious. If your in the area stop here for lunch or dinner. BTW also a BYOB.

tGFrshVS3Yj0oYeloLTWGA.text: Got take out from this place. It was very easy to place the order online and go pick it up at the selected time. It is still cash only like everyone else mentioned. But they do have an ATM inside available. My order was ready when I got there. One thing I like to place an takeout order over the phone better is that they usually have it ready fairly quick even sometimes the restaurant would say it will take 20-25 minutes. But the time available to choose from was at least half hour later. So that the food would not be fresh off the stove. But an online system does help smooth the ordering process.  I got the drunken noodle and pad Thai  which are my usual go to dishes. The spicy level was not spicy enough but the portion was generous. The taste was great but could use more sauce. All in all, it was a very good experience.

ZiMuAlhK6ewfakvonlmzNQ.text: There are many interesting dishes that I've never heard of before. We ordered the Chiang Mai Curry, which was really flavorful and spicy. I liked the combination of the noodles and curry a lot! I also had my favorite Thai dish: Pad See Ew. The Pad See Ew here was good and didn't disappoint!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Curry
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad See Ew

s48_WzpKAdyi4NxshNrzWA.text: Craving Thai in downtown Pittsburgh? Noodlehead is here for you! :D  Never would have thought that I'd be able to get legit delicious Asian baos (bread buns) or noodles at a cafe called Noodlehead, but whaddya know.  Being a hipster spot, the wait here to sit can take some time. Once you're seated, service is pretty fast.   Pulled pork steam buns || $7 Tender pulled pork & crisp cucumber slices wrapped in two steamed buns. Rather pricey since each little bun turns out to be $3.50. But if you have the cash, these are definitely tasty snacks you'll savor.   Pad Thai with Shrimp || $9.50 Nice portion of noodles, bean sprouts, and shrimp. The noodles are cooked perfectly al dente with a nice chew. Loved the sauce and dish overall. Would definitely recommend ordering this as an entree.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai with shrimp ($9.50).
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pulled pork steam buns ($7).

azNLDIhtO8uVLgPnaSGPDQ.text: Noodlehead is such a unique approach to Thai cuisine and the flavor does not disappoint.   A few faves are the sweet potatoes triangles, spring rolls, and the Chang mai curry.   When eating at Noodlehead, keep in mind a few things: they won't seat you without your whole party and they don't take reservations, they don't have a phone so order online or dine in only, they are BYOB and cash only with an ATM available. All I can say is WORTH. IT.

JtjFiCY2z00PEru0ft3pWA.text: Probably my favorite spot for noodles in Pittsburgh. Their different noodle bowls are all delicious as is their pad Thai. The real reason I like it so much however is because of the extremely reasonable prices and the spice. If you really really like spicy noodles, this is the place to go. They have a scale of 1-5 and five is EXTREMELY hot but at the same time the heat does not diminish the flavor. This place will have you coming back again and again.

I9Gw6raSVgmPvAr9GYbmnw.text: Top-notch place. The food was amazing and the service was on top of their game despite the place being packed. I had the pad thai noodles with chicken and I loved the portion size. You can easily make 2 meals out of the serving. I also had the pork dumplings which is great appetizer for whatever your meal is. It would even make a good midday snack. The pork was juicy and tender and the sauce that is paired with it was also a good compliment. I can't wait to come back and try everything on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

5F-XM5F1FoT1V85h4dheAg.text: Noodlehead is one of my go-to restaurants here. It's inexpensive yet delicious and is BYOB. Some of the dishes have an American twist to it which is really good. I highly recommend the street noodles and chiang mai curry (sometimes I eat the noodles then take the curry home and add rice to it to make 2 meals out of 1). You can expect to get stuffed here and leave extremely satisfied especially if you stop by Millie's ice cream next door for dessert.   It's usually crowded on Friday/Saturday nights so arrive early

NTcH716mzwaj40xsoMkaow.text: Delicious food and the soups are very well priced!   $6.50 for a large bowl of delicious noodle soup? Can't really beat that. However, they only have 2 soup options. We got the love boat and although it says it's in a spicy broth, not the spicy lime broth, it seemed to have a lime flavor as well. For this, we only got the 2 spice level and it was pretty mild. Good flavor and overall a great dish.  We also ordered the $9.50 street noodle #1 with the thai fried chicken. It's a rice noodle dish with a light sauce on it so it doesn't sit heavy or make you feel groggy. It's refreshing and the crunch of the bean sprouts and chicken adds some texture. Again, got the level 2 spice and it was again, pretty mild.   Lastly, we ordered the $9.50 chiang mai curry. This dish is honestly more like a soup with the amount of curry they give. The curry wasn't super thick but definitely not the same as a clear broth soup. The coconut flavor isn't overpowering like it is at most other places, but it's still there. It comes served with like a crispy, dry noodle on the top. It adds a crunch but is a bit hard to eat since they don't break apart that easy, but there are also the soft egg noodles in the curry itself. It comes with plenty of chicken and it's a very filling dish. I ordered it with a level 4 spice and the heat builds but it's a great kind of heat and flavor that you often find in thai dishes.  Overall, the food was amazing, but their menu isn't that large. The dishes have the traditional thai flavors and it stays True to that and that's probably what causes the menu to be a bit smaller. The seating isn't great. They only have a couple floor-level tables and they seem to be for larger parties, the rest are high-top tables with tall stools. Also, keep in mind that they are CASH ONLY, so make sure you have cash on you, although they say they have an ATM on site for those who need it.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Love boat
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street Noodle #1
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Noodles

ONztR5bnkFiGpptEj_ldgg.text: I love the food here, very affordable and very delicious! My only complaint is that it can be impossible to get a table. I've had success at 3pm on a Sunday and 5pm on a Thursday. Otherwise, if you want to come during a normal meal time, expect to put your name down, head down the street for a drink, and come back for dinner 1 - 2 hours later. They will call you when your table is almost ready, so no need to stick around while you wait.  My favorites are probably the See Yew and the Chiang Mai Curry (both with tofu) at spice level 2, but everything is delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green Curry Linguine

ZfeWEa01E7Nx6pCxpKPFYg.text: This place is my all time favorite. They serve a good portion of noodles. I ordered my all time favorite Pad Thai noodles with shrimp and my husband had Chiang Mai Curry. Everything was delicious. My husband loved the curry which we tried for the first time. Had a great time with friends here.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chiang Mai Curry
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai noodles

0YJwZ2Bod-_9mGKYUBWOpA.text: The menu was simple. Not an overabundance of choices.  The decor was interesting. Everything tasted very fresh. I ordered the meal with the shrimp tempura. It was cooked perfectly. May have been the best shrimp I've ever had. The breading was very light and fried perfectly to a golden brown. I am a big fan of spicy food. I ordered my food at a spice level 3 and I'm not sure I could have handled much hotter! I would decently downgrade the spice if you are unsure.

sRp-Dk1scLg-E46g1UnEww.text: Very busy and cash only! Be prepared for a wait, but it's so worth it. We couldn't get in on Saturday night so we ordered takeout when they opened Sunday at noon before we hit the road for our road trip.   Hog wings come  three to an order with a sliced pickles that had a slight hint of spice to them. Absolutely loved them and perfect portion to get you ready for your entree.   Love boat soup because the "spicy broth" on the menu caught my eye.   Chicken see yew was a keeper! Excellent flavors and perfect spice (level 4) aka: Thai spice. Everything was fresh and tender

YWLHj0Bol2zXd-X9NBbbww.text: The problem is this place gets hyped up a lot. The food was average in comparison to other noodle options,  but the service was good and people were friendly. I wouldn't go back as my first choice.

JhO6NYUYixElrzWnPuLnRg.text: A+ Thai--great food, great ambience, great prices! Can't go wrong with delicious Thai food and BYOB especially when it's under $10. Watch out for the wait as there's noreservations, but it's definitely worth it!!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

I9zqG0lYElbpG_aLycLOoQ.text: This place is amazing the food was delicious. I ordered one of the curries and highly recommend. They only accept cash so be prepared. My only recommendation is that they begin to accept credit cards.

CsFRY90Yd24G-GVQuufm0Q.text: Came here for lunch with some friends and the place was pretty packed. This is a cash only spot which I was unaware of. The food was good but nothing to rave on about. Could have been bigger portions in my opinion. Overall it was alright.

Z8y5LdeQYRuTQIzBjhzx_A.text: Noodlehead is unpretentious and authentic. The prices are perfect and portions are large. Everything is made to your tastes - so be careful and confident in the spice level you order. If you go too hot (or if you don't) make a stop at Millie's next door for ice cream.

K4EOqcdEkJZkI8ewIVPlcQ.text: This place is awesome! I have the hardest time convincing my bf to get thai food but he loved it here and I definitely agree.  We ordered the steamed pork buns which were the perfect texture - the buns were soft and kind of chewy, the meat tender and well flavored with cucumber.  I ordered the Chiang Mai curry which was amazing! Really good texture to the noodles, the spices were on point and the chicken and veggies were perfectly done. The presentation is also nice.   My bf ordered the shrimp street noodles. The tempura coating was crunchy and not too oily - perfect. The sauce/base was also very very good on this dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

PNcdB7mAcSwU6R9TTNRTGQ.text: Upon entering I was immediately amazed. Its so simply decorated that it almost looks picture perfect. Very mellow. I ordered the shrimp Pad Thai spice level 1 and the pork belly buns my significant other ordered the street noodles two spice level 2. Not even 5 minutes after we put in our order the pork belly buns arrived at the table. Before I even finished my bun our noodles came out. The wait time altogether was less than 10 minutes! The quickest ive every gotten food after ordering. Now before I get into the taste keep in mind ive never eaten Thai food before. This has been my first encounter with it and i honestly dont even know what i was expecting. But i was blown away! I took one bite of my pad Thai and was immediately in love. The spice was just right for my liking and the amount that you get per order is enough for two! My boyfriends street noodles were the bomb and honestly I think i liked his better. There was nothing wrong with mine I just prefered the taste of his dish. Overall our expieriance was fantastic and we will definitely be back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp Pad Thai Spice Level 1
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork Belly Buns

nOfkRszxY4uaSKDaGmOHEA.text: Great food. Friendly staff. And my three year old son loved it!   We had the pork belly steamed buns, spring rolls and street noodles number 1. All delicious!

9AeHs9xaGJTDLbqXcTNN-g.text: There's a cool, sort of hip ambiance to the place. They have great pork bun appetizers and they take their spice level seriously for the noodles. It makes great takeout too! It is cash only though, and sometimes parking is tough to find.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Street noodle #1 (Thai fried chicken) and Chiang Mai curry (coconut milk curry sauce), both $9
Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pulled pork belly steam buns appetizer, $6

qWwA2Bi587-t73mEPTGt8w.text: Good ambiance.   Food is good, but not particularly great. The Pad Thai is not really that flavorful. The Pad See Yew is good. This place is on the spicier side, if you do request spice.   They only accept cash, which is probably for sketchy tax purposes, but at least there's an ATM.

IWtZLU4uFYYSCr01IwEtwA.text: A cute and ambient location with a small but perfect menu. I loved the spice and heat level in my noodles. The price is perfect for the high quantity and quality of food you'll get!

NS0Nu8AQl3DJvKsNNnNfew.text: I thought the ambiance was neat-- definitely has rustic, cozy charm. I went with some friends on a rainy, Saturday afternoon and enjoyed our time there. I had the Pad Thai (which even though I love spicy things, I kept the spiciness to a minimum due to my friend's prior experience) and thought it was delicious. There was a hearty serving so I took half home and had it for dinner. Also, you can't beat that Millie's is just a few doors up!

6kFc8f2gbzdaI5MtRxs2Sg.text: This is my favorite restaurant of all time. Amazing, laid back, gorgeous rustic ambiance. Service is always friendly. Most of all, this is some of the most amazing food you will ever eat with equally amazing prices. Nothing is over $9 and you will get a huge portion no matter what you order. It's also BYOB. I seriously could not ask for more...I'm going into my senior year of college in Pittsburgh and I'm so sad that once I graduate I can't go anymore so I'm going to go every month!  My favorites are the chiang Mai noodles and the love boat soup. Skip the basic safe option of pad Thai here, the rest of the options are so so so delicious and too good to miss out on!   If you gave this place a bad review, you have issues and you are the devil in human form :)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Every single thing on the menu is amazing

kJDfJYWvc9Noe6ejB0j-gg.text: Noodlehead was a VERY delicious Thai restaurant! First off, it's CASH ONLY but they have an ATM in the restaurant. They are also BYOB. I came here with my friends and we all had a fabulous time. They do not take reservations and will only seat you when the entire party is present. We came here on a Thursday night and it was very busy, but we had a group of 8 and were seated at the back of the restaurant within 5 minutes because the large table was available for larger parties. My friends have all been here and some of them get Noodlehead once a week! I decided to finally try it and the food was delicious! I eat a lot, but the portion size was large and more than fair for the price. Because I knew the portion size was large, I had Pad See Yew with tofu and I split it with my friend. We ordered a spice level of 4 out of 5, but I actually had to add more sriracha (I love very spicy food)... I recommend that if you are sensitive to spice, you order less of a spice level because you can always add spice but not take it away. My friends and I also ordered the Cold Lemongrass Honey Iced Tea, which is only $2.50 and came with free refills. I highly recommend you get the tea... it was one of the best teas I have ever drank (not too sweet but flavorful and delicious). The service was a bit slow and the waiter was not the most attentive, but the restaurant was busy and the food made up for it. If you don't have time to wait, I suggest ordering takeout!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodlehead - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad See Yew with Tofu and Cold Lemongrass Honey Iced Tea

JkjNkEMm7ns2hUaVlQClzA.text: Came here for an early dinner with my mom tonight. These guys are cash only, so make sure you're prepared before you come. I lucked out and got a parking spot right in front and was seated immediately. We started with the pork sticky buns (so good!) and I got the Chiang Mai Curry, and my mom got the Kee Mao. Both were really good, but my mom said hers was a bit too spicy, even when she asked for it to not be spicy. If I liked close, I'd return here. Waiters were friendly and the meal was very reasonably priced.

XBqxORFF7I6XvC_OEni6hA.text: The place is really good, nice and cozy.  Overall rating:  Quality - 5/5 Money - 4.5/5 Vegetarian - yes Ambience- 3.5/5

Qw9bvuprFGrqx7dR7eNM1A.text: Came here during lunch hours and it was packed! I got seated for 2 right when we walked in though. Great ambiance and in a great neighborhood. Huge portion for being under $10 each dish.   1. Pad thai with shrimp with spciey level 2: Tons of shrimps, however I was questioning if they're frozen since they're small and had no flavour. Usually my paid Thai comes with fresh shrimp with the tail still on it, less shrimps but bigger shrimps. The noodles was all cut up which I don't like. You're suppose to have long noodlds for prosperity! Spicey level 2 was fine for me who can't handle spcieiness at all, just the right amount of kick. They did have the flavour after I added the lime juice to it. It was okay for a fast food kind of pad Thai but I've had better.   2. Pad kee mao with tofu and spicy level 5: Bf had this and rated it 2 stars. Had a bit of flavour but he said he had better. Said it wasn't spicey at all but he has a high tolerance. Tofu was cubes and didn't have much flavour, very bland. Had better food (in Thailand)   Overall, great spot for a fast food style Thai food at a reasonable price (under $10 each dish) and huge portion, you'll be full!
